Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Deciduous tooth emergence, nutritional status, and weaning and feeding decisions in the Brazilian Amazon

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research investigates how prenatal and postnatal nutrition relate to dental eruption and, in turn, the role of the developing dentition in mothers' weaning and feeding decisions. Weaning age is a critical life history characteristic because of the recognized relationship between breastfeeding and inter-birth intervals, and, ultimately, mothers' lifetime reproductive success. Links among weaning age, maternal condition, and infant nutrition and growth have been found in both non-human primates and humans. In addition, human mothers use infants' growth and developmental status as a cue when making weaning and feeding decisions. This research, by doctoral student Jennifer Spence (Ohio State University), under the guidance of Dr. Guatelli-Steinberg, addresses a relatively unexplored yet significant question: how the developing dentition is involved in these relationships.

Using anthropometric assessment and ethnographic methods, this research 1) employs a reliable technique of gauging gestation duration to accurately evaluate the association between prenatal maternal nutritional status and postnatal infant nutritional status, and the timing of deciduous (primary) tooth emergence; 2) determines the extent to which the timing of deciduous tooth emergence is related to the age at which the weaning process begins; and 3) investigates how the presence of deciduous teeth affects mothers' weaning and feeding decisions. It is hypothesized that both maternal and infant nutrition are associated with the timing of deciduous tooth emergence, which is in turn predicted to influence weaning and feeding decisions. This project is set among Ribeirinho populations in the eastern Brazilian Amazon, an area characterized by nutritional stress and with variation in weaning and feeding practices.

This research is part of a STEM initiative familiarizing underserved public-school students with the social sciences, particularly anthropology. The project promotes collaboration with Brazilian non-academics through inclusion of local women in data collection and academics through a university seminar. A campaign is planned to create and disseminate nontechnical material in local communities to encourage good nutrition and dental health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Jennifer E. Spence has completed research for her dissertation, “Deciduous tooth emergence, nutritional status, and infant feeding decisions in the Brazilian Amazon,” supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant. A biological anthropologist, Spence spent 20 months in a rural area in the Brazilian Amazon basin investigating the relationships among maternal and infant nutrition, dental development, and infant feeding practices. In addition to collecting quantitative and qualitative data to test hypotheses about how the developing dentition factors into early life, Spence collaborated with local public health agents and regional university scholars on projects related to dental development, infant feeding practices, and oral health.

During the project period, Spence worked with expectant mothers and their infants to investigate two primary questions. First, she is interested in how an expectant mother’s nutrition during pregnancy and an infant’s postnatal nutrition relate to the development of the deciduous (primary or baby) teeth, especially the age at which these teeth erupt into the mouth. Second, Spence seeks to understand why mothers decide to stop breastfeeding and introduce other liquids and foods to their infants. For example, her research examines whether an infant’s growth and development—including the presence of teeth—serve as a signal, what cultural attitudes influence maternal decisions, and how mothers draw on other biological, cultural, behavioral, and material factors when they make choices about what to feed their infants. In addition to augmenting our comprehension of variation in dental development worldwide, Spence’s research utilizes the methodologies of both biological and cultural anthropology to understand the relationship between dental development and human life history (the important changes and events that occur during life) not just in contemporary, living populations but in archaeological and paleontological contexts as well.

As part of outreach in the rural communities where her research was focused, Spence organized and delivered informative and educational public talks on oral health during pregnancy, infant dental care and teething symptoms, and family dental hygiene. Spence also collaborated with regional health clinics to understand the outcomes of breastfeeding promotion and support programs. While conducting fieldwork, Spence mentored a Brazilian female graduate student earning a postgraduate degree in anthropology, a relatively new and developing field in Brazil, in anthropometric and ethnographic methods. In addition, Spence was invited by faculty in the Graduate Program in Health, the Environment, and Society in the Amazon at the Federal University of Pará to present her research, talk about her fieldwork and funding experiences, and discuss how the field of anthropology is positioned in an international context.

Spence’s research in Brazil forms the basis of her dissertation. To be completed in 2017, the dissertation contributes to the discipline of anthropology by incorporating the dentition into our understanding of the relationships among human growth and development, infant feeding practices, and human life history.


Last Modified: 07/15/2016
Modified by: Jennifer E Spence
